UnitType.Backstory: "I seek no mercenaries; the Silver Swordsmen and their ilk are unwelcome in the ranks of my army. What I seek are heroes - those who wish to make bettering this world their life's adventure!" These words - uttered at the nadir of the Nobles Revolt, when the armies of Procipinee surrounded Relias and his companions at the foot of Mount Essa - remain the rallying cry for all Altar's soldiers. This is an army of adventurers - many of whom are famous in their own right for the quests they have completed - an army that will sometimes dare the impossible and often achieve it.

"I seek no mercenaries; the Silver Swordsmen and their ilk are unwelcome in the ranks of my army. What I seek are heroes - those who wish to make bettering this world their life's adventure!" These words - uttered at the nadir of the Nobles Revolt, when the armies of Procipinee surrounded Relias and his companions at the foot of Mount Essa - remain the rallying cry for all Altar's soldiers. This is an army of adventurers - many of whom are famous in their own right for the quests they have completed - an army that will sometimes dare the impossible and often achieve it.

All who wear the colors of this army, from commander to common foot-soldier, can trace their lineage back to the great kingdoms of the pre-cataclysmic era - to Coriopolis, Zad-Zabril, and even fabled Antheros. The blood of the channelers of old runs in their veins; they know and are unafraid of using this power to aid them in combat, both as shield and sword, in defense and attack. The commander who would engage this army in battle must possess a similar familiarity with the enchanter's art.

All who wear the colors of this army, from commander to common foot-soldier, can trace their lineage back to the great kingdoms of the pre-cataclysmic era - to Coriopolis, Zad-Zabril, and even fabled Antheros. The blood of the channelers of old runs in their veins; they know and are unafraid of using this power to aid them in combat, both as shield and sword, in defense and attack. The commander who would engage this army in battle must possess a similar familiarity with the enchanter's art.

You sealed yourself within the buried city of Calebethon, and toiled as each light went out. As the darkness crept through Calebethon, there was a rising tide of screams and madness. It would be unjust to say that the citizens became as animals, because animals were never so cruel or afraid.
Eventually the darkness claimed those voices too, and the city settled to the gentle sounds of ragged breath and the drip of blood, flesh and filth. When the last light of Calebethon finally went out, you could only hear echoes of your great city in the darkness. You have no memories of those last, horrible days.
When you awoke you walked through the streets of ancient Calebethon, and where you walked the long dead citizens of your city rose to follow.

Eventually the darkness claimed those voices too, and the city settled to the gentle sounds of ragged breath and the drip of blood, flesh and filth. When the last light of Calebethon finally went out, you could only hear echoes of your great city in the darkness. You have no memories of those last, horrible days.
When you awoke you walked through the streets of ancient Calebethon, and where you walked the long dead citizens of your city rose to follow.

These are miners by trade; they make cautious soldiers, content to assess a battle's progress from a fortified position, to rely less on tactical skill and more on superior equipment to provide them advantage. Many among them are innately resistant to the channeler's basic spells, a trait inherited from the greatest of their kind, Fierann Ma Tua of the Aivernach.

These are miners by trade; they make cautious soldiers, content to assess a battle's progress from a fortified position, to rely less on tactical skill and more on superior equipment to provide them advantage. Many among them are innately resistant to the channeler's basic spells, a trait inherited from the greatest of their kind, Fierann Ma Tua of the Aivernach.

There are no more stalwart defenders than the armies of Kraxis; their ability to establish and protect near-unassailable battlefield positions is well-documented. Recall the siege of Morrania, the last of the great pre-cataclysmic battles between Man and Fallen, where four hundred Krax held off two thousand D'Rog fighters. Some may call them traitors, but the Krax have an unshakable belief in the righteousness of their cause, and an uncanny ability to persuade others to their side... a trait opposing commanders would do well to take note of.

Some may call them traitors, but the Krax have an unshakable belief in the righteousness of their cause, and an uncanny ability to persuade others to their side... a trait opposing commanders would do well to take note of.

The armies of Capitar have at their disposal the vast wealth of the great trading houses of old, money that lets them buy not just the best equipment, but the best fighters: mercenaries such as the Silver Swordsmen; archers whose skills rival the ninety-nine of Redstone; war horses bred from the stock of fabled Antheros. This great wealth buys influence in diplomatic councils as well as on the battlefield; a fact the seasoned commander would do well to keep in mind when forging alliances.

The armies of Capitar have at their disposal the vast wealth of the great trading houses of old, money that lets them buy not just the best equipment, but the best fighters: mercenaries such as the Silver Swordsmen; archers whose skills rival the ninety-nine of Redstone; war horses bred from the stock of fabled Antheros. This great wealth buys influence in diplomatic councils as well as on the battlefield; a fact the seasoned commander would do well to keep in mind when forging alliances.

Discipline is first, second, and third when building an effective fighting force. Little else matters.' These words - spoken by Vergaxa of the Quendar - remain the watchword for the commanders of this army. They will make slaves of any fighter they defeat in battle; they will conscript any banker, baker, or miner whose path they cross. From those slaves they will make soldiers, and from those soldiers, massive armies driven by fear of the lash, and inculcated with the discipline prescribed by Vergaxa centuries earlier.

They will make slaves of any fighter they defeat in battle; they will conscript any banker, baker, or miner whose path they cross. From those slaves they will make soldiers, and from those soldiers, massive armies driven by fear of the lash, and inculcated with the discipline prescribed by Vergaxa centuries earlier.

Once they were rebels; slaves fighting to shake off the chains of the Capitaran arenas. Now they are an army - brave and determined soldiers with a country of their own to defend. Yet by training and nature, Tarthans remain gladiators - used to fighting alone, or in small groups. They will strike quickly and retreat, never allowing themselves to get bogged down in a long, drawn-out conflict. Their commanders drill them constantly on all types of terrain, so that in combat they may move as quickly in swamp as on packed earth.

They will strike quickly and retreat, never allowing themselves to get bogged down in a long, drawn-out conflict. These are Elemental's most fearsome warriors; bred for battle, taught to strike without mercy and to ignore pain, to banish the words 'caution' and 'surrender' from their vocabulary. Whether you engage them in single combat, or fight them in phalanxes, you will learn the truth of those words attributed to Iskahar, last of Ereog's line, as he lay dying on the steppes of Engar. "It is no shame to perish to a superior foe."

Whether you engage them in single combat, or fight them in phalanxes, you will learn the truth of those words attributed to Iskahar, last of Ereog's line, as he lay dying on the steppes of Engar. "It is no shame to perish to a superior foe."

For a thousand years, following their banishment from Imperium, the Urxen roamed the great Umbran wastes. There, in the shadow of the mountain ranges ruled by the Titan Ilosa, she who became the Lady Umber, they forged a special relationship with the creatures of Elemental, a bond that not even the Cataclysm could break. Even now, the Urxen can call the great serpents of this world to their cause - the naja and the ophidian - and command them in battle.

For a thousand years, following their banishment from Imperium, the Urxen roamed the great Umbran wastes. There, in the shadow of the mountain ranges ruled by the Titan Ilosa, she who became the Lady Umber, they forged a special relationship with the creatures of Elemental, a bond that not even the Cataclysm could break. Even now, the Urxen can call the great serpents of this world to their cause - the naja and the ophidian - and command them in battle.

Resoln is a new country - but its fighters draw their strength from the old powers, from the magics of the Dread Lord Curgen, most powerful of all the Titans to ever walk upon Elemental. The armies of Resoln discount the use of much equipment the typical soldier relies upon, and instead make use of the enchantments, spells, and creatures that are their birthright.
